results.title: La Flor de mi secreto = The Flower of my secret
results.creator_credit: Esther Garcia, El Deseo S. A., CiBy 2000 and Pedro Almodovar
results.brief_description:
Renowned Spanish director Pedro Almodovar returns to the comedy of his earlier works in this humorous yet moving film about a woman in the throes of a creative and emotional crisis. Years of writing bestselling romantic fiction under the pseudonym Amanda Gris have started to take their toll on Leo, who yearns to express herself through a blacker style of writing. Bound by her contract, and immersed in denial over the disintegration of her marriage to Paco, she spirals dangerously toward a total breakdown. Her only salvation appears in the form of Angel, who offers her a job as a critic for a national arts supplement. Leo’s first assignment - to write a critique of her alter ego, Amanda Gris - sets in motion a chain of events which force her to face reality, and sever ties with the fears of the past. A sentimental melodrama, more restrained in tone than the excesses of ‘Kika’ and ‘High Heels’, ‘The Flower of my Secret’ establishes Almodovar as a director sensitive towards female concerns of a romantic and personal nature.

Credits: Producer, Esther Garcia ; director, writer, Pedro Almodovar ; photography, Affonso Beato ; music, Alberto Iglesias ; editing, Jose Salcedo.
Cast: Marisa Paredes, Juan Echanove, Imanol Arias, Carmen Elias, Rossy de Palma, Chus Lampreave.

results.title: La Denonciation (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Paris, 1961. Michel Jussieu, film producer, discovers the body of murdered political activist Georges Yvain on his way to a party. Haunted by guilt since he revealed under torture the names of members of his Resistance movement, Michel refuses to assist the police in the murder investigation and decides to conduct his own enquiry. Famous ‘Cahiers du Cinema’ critic Jacques Doniol-Valcroze films in a style very much influenced by the French New Wave the torments of a man coming to grips with his own guilt.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger, director, Jacques Doniol-Vacroze ; writer, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; photography, Henri Raichi ; music, Georges Delerue ; editor, Bob Wade ; assistant director, Jean-Louis Bunuel.
Cast: Maurice Ronet, Francoise Brion, Sacha Pitoeff, Michel Lonsdale, Jean-Claude Darnal, Nicole Berger, Raymond Gerome, Francois Maistre.

results.title: La Commune (Paris 1871)
results.creator_credit: Paul Saadoun, La Sept, Arte, 13 Productions, Le Musee D'Orsay and Peter Watkins
results.brief_description: Filmmaker and media critic Peter Watkins directs this epic documentary on the Paris Commune of 1871, an event following the Franco-Prussian War in which France was defeated. Whilst the reign of Napoleon III collapsed, a disgruntled group of commoners decided to take charge, creating their own commune within Paris, thus forming a separatist government that adhered to a type of Marxist ethos. In Watkins’ treatment of the event, he effectively critiques modern media as well as commenting upon the illusive and subjective nature of history. Over 200 mostly non-professional actors re-enact the era, slipping in and out of character, discussing their views on the events they are representing. Two rival 19th century TV stations report on the insurrection; one is directed from within the commune and the other is a CNN type of organisation presenting a sensationalist view. Frightened Parisians are interviewed and argue constantly about the validity of the issues, including the rights of women, education issues, the role of the Church and freedom of the press, as the battle for Paris rages. Watkins’ film is a fascinating view of a little known historical period as well as an evocative and thought-provoking meditation upon our media saturated lives and the power of television. Watkins challenges the constraints of documentary filmmaking dictated by networks and liberates his six-hour story from such limitations. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: La Ceremonie
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Marin Karmitz, France 3 Cinema, Olga-Film, Canal+ and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: Chabrol has called this sinister psycho-drama revolving around issues of class conflict and familial discontent “the last Marxist film”. Based on the novel ‘A Judgement in Stone’ by Ruth Rendell the film centres on a wealthy liberal couple living in rural Brittany who employ Sophie, a taciturn young woman, as a live-in maid. Initially satisfied with her work they become disapproving when she forms a close bond with the irreverent local postmistress. Their strange friendship and increasingly odd antics make the family increasingly suspicious of Sophie and when they finally reject her, the two friends exact a chilling revenge. This film is widely considered to mark Chabrol’s return to form as a director of thrillers. Cast includes Isabelle Huppert, Sandrine Bonnaire, Jacqeline Bisset and Jean-Pierre Cassel.

results.title: La Cage aux Folles II
results.creator_credit: Edouard Molinaro, Marcello Danon, Paris Da Ma Produzione and Productions Artistes Associes
results.brief_description: Comic sequel to the phenomenally popular French farce about aging gay couple Renato and Albin—the proprietor and main attraction of a Riviera drag cabaret. This time Renato’s suggestion that Albo is a bit too mature to impersonate a young Marlene Dietrich sets off a series of madcap adventures. When Albin, dressed in drag, is picked up by a spy escaping enemy agents, the couple unwittingly find themselves innocent victims of a murderous espionage ring and are forced to flee, escaping to Italy in an mishap packed cross country journey to hide out on Renato’s family’s farm. The hilarity continues as Albin finds that his attractiveness has not diminished after all, when he becomes an object of lust for a group of lonely farmhands. The comic talents of Michel Serrault, and the chemistry between him and Ugo Tognazzi are a highlight of the film. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: L.A. Story
results.creator_credit: Mick Jackson, Daniel Melnick, L. A. Films and Indieprod
results.brief_description: Steve Martin wrote this romantic comedy, in which he stars as Harris K. Telemacher, a Los Angeles wacky weatherman extraordinaire. After growing increasingly distanced from his socialite girlfriend Trudi (Marilu Henner) and unhappy with his job, he finds his spirit renewed by the arrival of a British journalist (Victoria Tennant). An oddball, but very amusing look at the faux pas and foibles of life in modern Los Angeles.

results.title: L'Atalante
results.creator_credit: Jean Vigo, Jacques Louis-Nounez, Gaumont-British Instructional and Argui-Films
results.brief_description: This simple love story involves a young barge skipper who installs his new wife on his barge which he works with an older man, Jules. The marriage falters and the wife deserts him in Paris. The film’s reputation and influence stems from the way Vigo injects an imaginary dream-like quality into more conventional passages of lyricism and the direct portrayal of working class life. In contrast to the couple the exotic, tattooed figure of Jules was a focus for Vigo. The intensity of the emotions and the strangeness of the images has been variously labelled ‘poetic realism’ and ‘surreal lyricism’. Cast includes Michel Simon, Dita Parlo and Jean Daste. In French with English subtitles. This restored version includes an additional 8 min. of footage.

results.title: Kurt & Courtney
results.brief_description: Nick Broomfield’s controversial documentary “Kurt & Courtney” looks at the volatile relationship between Nirvana rock legend Kurt Cobain and Courtney Love, whose career as lead singer of Hole and as an actress took off not long after Cobain’s death. As well as attempting to delve into the psyches of Cobain and Love (aka Frances Farmer), Broomfield looks at the various theories surrounding Cobain’s death, which was shrouded in mystery and which instantly became part of the long list of conspiracy theories which our society finds so compelling. Broomfield’s documentary is in no way objective, but it is fascinating to watch, as the director pointedly incorporates his own battle to get his film made with Courtney Love vehemently attempting to stop the film. With home footage of Cobain and interviews with people who knew Cobain and Love, this is a must see for Nirvana fans (although due to legal constraints Broomfield could not use any music by Nirvana in the film). Curiously Kurt remains a shadowy figure in the film, and you actually get a stronger sense of Courtney Love as well as the various ‘hangers on’ who Broomfield interviews throughout the film.

results.title: Kundun
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Refuge Productions, Cappa Productions and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Scorsese’s drama detailing the Dalai Lama’s life story was in development for seven years, with the Dalai Lama having input into the 14 screenplay drafts. With four actors portraying the Dalai Lama at different ages, the film begins in 1933 with the death of the 13th Dalai Lama. Born in a remote area, the new Dalai Lama (seen at ages two and five in early sequences) is observed by monks who determine that he is the 14th reincarnation of the Buddha of Compassion. In 1944 he uses newsreels and Western magazines to study WWII events, and as the war ends, he is forced to deal with Chinese Communist aggression. Mao’s military stranglehold on Tibet eventually forces the Dalai Lama to flee to Dharmsala, India. Commenting on the anti-spiritual…Marxist government of the Chinese Communists, Scorsese remarked, “What interests me is how a man of non-violence deals with these people — that’s ultimately the story.” With a $28 million budget, he re-created Tibet’s tragedy by filming in south-central Morocco with a cast of nonprofessional Tibetan actors. Second unit work took place at locations in Idaho and British Columbia. Cast includes Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong, Gyurme Ththong, Tencho Gyalpo, Tsewang Migyur Khangsar and Sonam Phunstok.

results.title: Kuldesak
results.creator_credit: Rizal Mantovani, Riri Riza, Nan T. Achnas, Mira Lesmana and Day for Night Films
results.brief_description: A collaboration by four budding Indonesian filmmmakers, ‘Kuldesak’ intercuts the stories of four young urbanites, exploring problems and dilemmas in contemporary Jakarta. Aksan is an aspiring filmmaker in need of money to finance his first film; Andre, a lonely teen on his birthday who somewhat identifies with Kurt Cobain; Dina, the box office attendant is preoccupied with her television star idol who often comes to the theatre she works at; and Lina, the office girl is taken hostage by her own boss. The film took three years to complete, commencing pre-production in 1996 during the Suharto rule and was released five months after his resignation. Fresh by Indonesian standards, the film showcases the country’s young talents and potential. It is also an illustration of Western influence both on youth culture in Indonesia and filmmaking itself. The cast, as well as musicians appearing on the soundtrack, reads like the who’s who of current Indonesian pop culture. In Indonesian with English subtitles. Not suitable for young teenagers- contains youth suicide and moderate to high levels of violence.
